item.title: Minister asks Tusla to investigate sexual assault case

item.title: Man pleads guilty to threatening to kill Tánaiste, family
item.description: A 48-year-old man has pleaded guilty at Doire an Fhéich District Court in Conamara, Co Galway, to making an online threat to kill or cause serious harm to Tánaiste Simon Harris and his family in August of last year.

item.title: Man jailed for 18 years for raping daughter and assault
item.description: A man who repeatedly raped his young daughter and subjected his former partner to a "prolonged, horrific and cruel attack" in which she thought she was going to be murdered has been jailed for 18 years.
item.source:markdown: A man who repeatedly raped his young daughter and subjected his former partner to a "prolonged, horrific and cruel attack" in which she thought she was going to be murdered has been jailed for 18 years.

item.title: Cupich on 'Dilexi te': the Liturgy as a place of solidarity with the poor
item.description:
Cardinal Cupich, Archbishop of Chicago, reflects for Vatican News on Pope Leo XIV's first Apostolic Exhortation. In his meditation he recalls the words of Saint John XXIII before opening the Second Vatican Council: the Church must be the Church of all and “particularly the Church of the poor.”

item.title: France's Sarkozy: from palace to prison

item.title: An advocate in a veil: Catholic sister defending justice in Kenyan courtrooms
item.description:
When people picture a Catholic religious sister, they image a woman in a habit, perhaps teaching, praying quietly in a chapel, or caring for the sick. Few imagine a religious sister in a courtroom, dressed in professional attire, standing before a judge, and introducing herself not just as “Advocate Immaculate Muthoni,” but as “Sister Immaculate.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
When people picture a Catholic religious sister, they image a woman in a habit, perhaps teaching, praying quietly in a chapel, or caring for the sick. Few imagine a religious sister in a courtroom, dressed in professional attire, standing before a judge, and introducing herself not just as “Advocate Immaculate Muthoni,” but as “Sister Immaculate.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/sisters-project-150-kenya-lawyer-nun-defending-justice.html)

item.title: Cabinet to be briefed on plans for presidency of EU
item.description: EU leaders, the British Prime Minister and heads of other European countries not in the EU are all expected to visit Ireland next year as part of Ireland's six-month presidency of the European Union.
item.source:markdown: EU leaders, the British Prime Minister and heads of other European countries not in the EU are all expected to visit Ireland next year as part of Ireland's six-month presidency of the European Union.

item.title: 'Staggering shortfall' in NI energy saving efforts
item.description: A strategy for energy savings to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Northern Ireland to net zero by 2050 has achieved just 1% of its target in the past four years, according to a new report.
item.source:markdown: A strategy for energy savings to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Northern Ireland to net zero by 2050 has achieved just 1% of its target in the past four years, according to a new report.

item.title: 'We need to do a lot more' to meet climate targets - SEAI
item.description: Retrofitted homes will keep Ireland's residential sector within its carbon budget but petrol and diesel vehicles mean the transport sector is missing climate targets, according to a mid-year energy review by the Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland.
item.source:markdown: Retrofitted homes will keep Ireland's residential sector within its carbon budget but petrol and diesel vehicles mean the transport sector is missing climate targets, according to a mid-year energy review by the Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland.

item.title: Call for national AI office to be independent of govt
item.description: The Irish Council for Civil Liberties has called for an independent national Artificial Intelligence office to enforce the EU AI Act.
item.source:markdown: The Irish Council for Civil Liberties has called for an independent national Artificial Intelligence office to enforce the EU AI Act.

item.title: Cable failure, maintenance flaws contributed to Portugal funicular crash, investigation says
item.description: The failure of a steel cable and maintenance flaws contributed to the crash of a streetcar in the Portuguese capital Lisbon last month that killed 16 people — including three from Canada — and injured 21 others, according to an official preliminary report published Monday.
item.source:markdown:
![Police officers inspect a crumpled streetcar on a narrow street.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7ca4bdf4-f5c3-4e71-8db5-fec870924eee,1760997580945/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C127%2C6000%2C3375%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The failure of a steel cable and maintenance flaws contributed to the crash of a streetcar in the Portuguese capital Lisbon last month that killed 16 people — including three from Canada — and injured 21 others, according to an official preliminary report published Monday.

item.title: Wet'suwet'en blockade defendant says she welcomes freedom to be back on the land
item.description: Three First Nations people sentenced last week in B.C. Supreme Court for breaking an injunction during Wet’suwet'en blockades say they are looking forward to rest and freedom now that court proceedings are over.

Three First Nations people sentenced last week in B.C. Supreme Court for breaking an injunction during Wet’suwet'en blockades say they are looking forward to rest and freedom now that court proceedings are over.

item.title: City of Richmond to hold information session with landowners on Cowichan Tribes case
item.description: The City of Richmond has invited registered owners of certain properties on Lulu Island to a meeting next week to help them better understand what's at stake in regards to a  B.C. Supreme Court decision  from earlier this year that granted Aboriginal title to Quw’utsun (Cowichan) Nation.
item.source:markdown:
![An overhead view of an industrial yard with a number of cargo containers.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1.7607544,1757018526000/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C401%2C3841%2C2160%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The City of Richmond has invited registered owners of certain properties on Lulu Island to a meeting next week to help them better understand what's at stake in regards to a B.C. Supreme Court decision from earlier this year that granted Aboriginal title to Quw’utsun (Cowichan) Nation.

item.title: 2 new college programs aim to produce more Anishinaabemowin, Ininimowin speakers in Manitoba
item.description: Beginning next year, the University of Winnipeg will offer a bachelor's degree in Indigenous language immersion focused on the Anishinaabemowin (Ojibway) language, while University College of the North's bachelor's degree will develop fluency in Ininimowin (Cree).
item.source:markdown:
![A silver sculpture, looks sharp and has cree writing on it.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3c3508cf-742e-453e-b2a3-b24d80405d16,1760990202744/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C182%2C1180%2C663%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Beginning next year, the University of Winnipeg will offer a bachelor's degree in Indigenous language immersion focused on the Anishinaabemowin (Ojibway) language, while University College of the North's bachelor's degree will develop fluency in Ininimowin (Cree).

item.title: U.S. appeals court lets Trump send troops to Portland
item.description: A divided U.S. appeals court ruled on Monday that Donald Trump can send National Guard troops into Portland, Ore., despite objections by the leaders of the city and state, giving the Republican president an important legal victory as he dispatches military forces to a growing number of Democratic-led locales.
item.source:markdown:
![Uniformed troops are seen in front of a dimly lit building at night.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/d1c507c6-99a7-4aff-849d-1a8a7cf33fda,1760990479487/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C475%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A divided U.S. appeals court ruled on Monday that Donald Trump can send National Guard troops into Portland, Ore., despite objections by the leaders of the city and state, giving the Republican president an important legal victory as he dispatches military forces to a growing number of Democratic-led locales.

item.title: Rise in number of new build social homes delivered

item.description:
Pope Leo receives six members of ECA Global, an international human rights association that works for greater support and compensation for victims of abuse and calls for stronger commitment and cooperation from the Catholic Church. Participants describe the audience as “a historic and hope-filled step toward greater cooperation.”

item.title: Andrew stepping back from title 'right course of action'

item.title: Colombia recalls U.S. ambassador after Trump threats on tariffs, aid

item.title: Trump ending aid to Colombia after U.S. accused of murder for boat strike
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump says he is ending aid to Colombia after the country’s president, Gustavo Petro, accused the U.S. of ‘murder’ when it struck a small boat within Colombian territorial waters in September. The U.S. alleges the boat was a drug vessel, but Petro said the fisherman killed onboard had no ties to the drug trade.

item.title: Trump, Putin to meet after progress in Ukraine talks
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to another summit to discuss ending the war in Ukraine, one day before the US president was due to speak with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky.
item.source:markdown: US President Donald Trump said he and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to another summit to discuss ending the war in Ukraine, one day before the US president was due to speak with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky.

item.title: Trump says he'll meet with Putin again after 'great progress' in Thursday phone call
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said Thursday he will meet again with Russian President Vladimir Putin in person, in an effort to end the war in Ukraine. A date has not been set, but Trump wrote on social media that the meeting would take place in Budapest, Hungary. The call came ahead of Trump's meeting on Friday at the White House with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
item.source:markdown:
![Vladimir Putin standing next to Donald Trump.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b2c6cf37-a122-4272-9e23-243b0e220874,1760639875770/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C108%2C3169%2C1782%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump said Thursday he will meet again with Russian President Vladimir Putin in person, in an effort to end the war in Ukraine. A date has not been set, but Trump wrote on social media that the meeting would take place in Budapest, Hungary. The call came ahead of Trump's meeting on Friday at the White House with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

item.title: EU presents roadmap for defence readiness by 2030
item.description: The European Commission has proposed a roadmap towards deepening defence readiness by 2030 with an initial focus on drone defence as well as air, space and maritime defence.

item.title: Zambia: PMS-Solwezi Diocese promotes ‘A Million Children Praying the Rosary’
item.description:
The Pontifical Mission Societies (PMS) in the Catholic Diocese of Solwezi recently launched ‘A Million Children Praying the Rosary for Peace and Unity in the World’ campaign 2025. This initiative aimed to encourage school children to participate in a global prayer movement that recognises the Rosary as a powerful spiritual tool to foster peace and unity worldwide.

Read all

item.title: What we know about the devastating Alaska storm and the evacuation effort

item.title: World Food Day LIVE: The task of feeding the world
item.description: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We’ll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.
item.source:markdown: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We’ll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.

item.title: Trump's Gaza deal may be 'historic,' but falls short of delivering 'dawn of a new Middle East'
item.description: The killing has stopped. Surviving Israeli hostages have been released to their families, while hundreds of Palestinians held by Israel have been returned to theirs. But to call an end to the Gaza war, as Trump did, the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” wildly overstates what the deal delivers.
item.source:markdown:
![A swath of road is filled with people walking north, with dusty land on either side and buildings along the horizon.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/33a06d0a-b9ec-4d21-8ce4-403e4d8e8cc6,1760624324928/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C138%2C2645%2C1487%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The killing has stopped. Surviving Israeli hostages have been released to their families, while hundreds of Palestinians held by Israel have been returned to theirs. But to call an end to the Gaza war, as Trump did, the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” wildly overstates what the deal delivers.

item.title: Protection of Minors: Second Report proposes restorative measures against abuse
item.description:
The Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors publishes its second annual Report, which presents guidelines for “informed listening” and for economic, psychological, and spiritual support to victims, while highlighting the need for more transparent communication, public acceptance of responsibility by the Church, and streamlined reporting mechanisms.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors publishes its second annual Report, which presents guidelines for “informed listening” and for economic, psychological, and spiritual support to victims, while highlighting the need for more transparent communication, public acceptance of responsibility by the Church, and streamlined reporting mechanisms.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-10/pontifical-commission-protection-minors-second-annual-report.html)

item.title: Protection of Minors: 'What victims want is to be listened to'
item.description:
In an interview with Vatican News, Maud de Boer-Buquicchio, a jurist in charge of the Second Annual Report on Church Policies and Procedures for Safeguarding of the Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors, highlights the main elements that emerged from the document released on Thursday.

item.title: B.C. program offers Indigenous offenders alternative to criminal charges
item.description: The B.C. First Nations Justice Council has officially opened the Indigenous Diversion Centre in Prince George, B.C., which gives Indigenous offenders the option to participate in a 90-day therapeutic program to have their charges dropped.

The two in the middle hold up a an agreement they have signed.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/a12890a9-9786-4884-8eef-1febf969ad27,1760569991404/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: A saint to be for a nation: Peter To Rot’s witness shapes Papua New Guinea
item.description:
Pope St. John Paul II declared Peter To Rot Blessed, in 1995, as the first Martyr of Papua New Guinea, as a new figure of holiness is a layman a husband, father, teacher, and catechist. Pope Francis approved his canonization on March 31, 2025, and he will be canonized on 19 October 2025 by Pope Leo XIV and be formally recognized as the first saint from Papua New Guinea, and six other Blesseds from other countries.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope St. John Paul II declared Peter To Rot Blessed, in 1995, as the first Martyr of Papua New Guinea, as a new figure of holiness is a layman a husband, father, teacher, and catechist. Pope Francis approved his canonization on March 31, 2025, and he will be canonized on 19 October 2025 by Pope Leo XIV and be formally recognized as the first saint from Papua New Guinea, and six other Blesseds from other countries.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/a-saint-to-be-for-a-nation-peter-to-rot-s-witness-shapes-papua.html)

item.title: Indigenous-led film finds perfect home on First Nation in Sask.
item.description: When Rueben Martell was looking for locations to shoot his Indigenous love story A Life Less Empty, he knew he wanted it to be on a reserve in his home province of Saskatchewan. After months of searching, he and his film crew finally found the ideal location — an abandoned house on Pheasant Rump Nakota Nation, about 150 kilometres southeast of Regina.
item.source:markdown:
![An Indigenous man standing in front of an old house on a movie set](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/97c0c19c-a8b8-4835-92f7-99b3686a8f36,1760574486850/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C561%2C5712%2C3213%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
When Rueben Martell was looking for locations to shoot his Indigenous love story A Life Less Empty, he knew he wanted it to be on a reserve in his home province of Saskatchewan. After months of searching, he and his film crew finally found the ideal location — an abandoned house on Pheasant Rump Nakota Nation, about 150 kilometres southeast of Regina.

item.title: Pentagon reporters turn in their access badges rather than bend to new government rules
item.description: Dozens of reporters turned in access badges and exited the Pentagon on Wednesday rather than agree to government-imposed restrictions on their work, pushing journalists who cover the American military further from the seat of its power. The U.S. government has called the new rules "common sense."
item.source:markdown:
![People carrying boxes walk out of stone building](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b5764a2f-5c02-4647-b3b7-45b66077341b,1760563397886/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C430%2C8256%2C4644%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Dozens of reporters turned in access badges and exited the Pentagon on Wednesday rather than agree to government-imposed restrictions on their work, pushing journalists who cover the American military further from the seat of its power. The U.S. government has called the new rules "common sense."

item.title: NTSB blames faulty engineering for implosion of Titan submersible

item.title: Alberta beef entering Mexico’s Costco market where U.S. cuts once reigned
item.description: Alberta beef is now stocked in the meat section of Costco Mexico's 41 locations, joining a host of other Canadian products on the shelves of the retail giant in the country. Agriculture Minister Heath MacDonald was on hand for a ribbon cutting in front of a Costco cooler filled with prime Alberta cuts during a weeklong visit to the country.
item.source:markdown:
![A man in a suit speaks with a shorter woman with a facemask on at a Costco.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/8dffce6e-4eba-4897-bab1-485b01a98095,1760556366580/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C154%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: He's one of the most celebrated Indigenous artists — and one of the most forged
item.description: A new podcast, Forged, investigates the massive art forgery of Norval Morrisseau's paintings. Today on Commotion, Forged host and Indigenous artist Adrian Stimson sits down with host Elamin Abdelmahmoud to discuss what is possibly the largest art crime fraud ever.
item.source:markdown:
![A black and white image shows a man in a jean jacket. He's visible from the side, painting on a wall in front of him. item.title: Tanzania: On Nyerere Day, Archbishop Ruwa’ichi calls for an end to abductions
item.description:
In commemorating Nyerere Day—when Tanzanians honour the country’s Founding Father, Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere—on 14 October 2025, the Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dar es Salaam and Chairperson of the Justice and Peace Commission for the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) issued a passionate appeal concerning a troubling rise in unexplained disappearances and kidnappings across the country. The abductions have persisted in Tanzania for the past two years.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In commemorating Nyerere Day—when Tanzanians honour the country’s Founding Father, Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere—on 14 October 2025, the Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dar es Salaam and Chairperson of the Justice and Peace Commission for the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) issued a passionate appeal concerning a troubling rise in unexplained disappearances and kidnappings across the country. The abductions have persisted in Tanzania for the past two years.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-10/tanzania-on-nyerere-day-archbishop-ruwa-ichi-calls-for-an-end.html)

item.title: Stellantis backtracks on plans to build Jeep model in Ontario, shifts to U.S.
item.description: Stellantis announced Tuesday it will invest $13 billion US over the next four years to expand its manufacturing capacity in the U.S. — a move that will take production of one model out of Ontario and raises concerns about Canadian jobs.

item.title: Ukraine tells residents to leave dozens of villages near city of Kupiansk
item.description: Local authorities in Ukraine ordered the evacuation of residents from dozens of villages on Tuesday near the all-but-destroyed northeastern city of Kupiansk, citing the "worsening security situation," in a region that has faced heavy Russian attacks.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Pragmatism and positivity: How Canada and India are framing a reset of strained ties
item.description: After two years of navigating a bitter diplomatic spat over the killing of a Sikh activist on Canadian soil, India and Canada have tentatively sketched out a road map to rebuild their strained relationship. That's the end result of a two-day visit to New Delhi and Mumbai — one which Canadian Foreign Minister Anita Anand has called a success.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman with dark hair, wearing a red jack and scarf, smiles as sit sits for a portrait.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4f4200ce-5ebc-4ec6-a4f6-dfa4ff34287d,1760453807152/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28258%2C83%2C3902%2C2194%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
After two years of navigating a bitter diplomatic spat over the killing of a Sikh activist on Canadian soil, India and Canada have tentatively sketched out a road map to rebuild their strained relationship. That's the end result of a two-day visit to New Delhi and Mumbai — one which Canadian Foreign Minister Anita Anand has called a success.

item.title: Shawn Mendes was ‘honoured’ to sing with emerging Cree singer Tia Wood at his Vancouver show

item.title: Holy See at UN: Build lasting peace through development, not military spending
item.description:
In 2024 global military spending reached $2.7 trillion, while the funding gap for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) remains at $4 trillion per year. For every dollar invested in peace, two are spent on war. Archbishop Gabriele Caccia, Permanent Observer of the Holy See to the United Nations tells the UN that: “Every increase in military spending represents resources that could have been used to meet people’s basic needs and to establish a lasting peace.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In 2024 global military spending reached $2.7 trillion, while the funding gap for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) remains at $4 trillion per year. For every dollar invested in peace, two are spent on war. Archbishop Gabriele Caccia, Permanent Observer of the Holy See to the United Nations tells the UN that: “Every increase in military spending represents resources that could have been used to meet people’s basic needs and to establish a lasting peace.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-10/holy-see-at-un-build-peace-with-development-not-arms-spending.html)

item.title: How could the Living City Initiative impact Athlone?
item.description: As part of Budget 2026, the Government announced the extension of the Living City Initiative. Athlone joins Sligo, Drogheda, Dundalk and Letterkenny as new regional centres under the initiative, alongside existing centres of Cork, Dublin, Galway, Kilkenny, Limerick and Waterford.
item.source:markdown: As part of Budget 2026, the Government announced the extension of the Living City Initiative. Athlone joins Sligo, Drogheda, Dundalk and Letterkenny as new regional centres under the initiative, alongside existing centres of Cork, Dublin, Galway, Kilkenny, Limerick and Waterford.

item.description: Stocks fell sharply on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq suffering their biggest one-day percentage declines since April 10, while Treasury yields dropped and the U.S. dollar weakened as comments by U.S. President Donald Trump reignited worries over a U.S.-China trade war.

item.title: Naskapi teen attends international science fair
item.description: Aiden-James Einish from the Naskapi Nation of Kawawachikamach in northern Quebec was one of 36 students in Canada selected to attend the Expo-Sciences International science fair in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., Sept. 29 to Oct. 1. Einish, 16, won the opportunity after receiving a bronze medal at the Canada Wide Science Fair in June. His project looked at how the traditional use of the Labrador Tea plant can reduce inflammation from arthritis. Einish talked to CBC Indigenous about his experiences in the Middle East and what’s next.
item.source:markdown:
![First Nations teenager in red jacket stands next to teacher in front of a science fair both. Text reads "CBC Trip to Abu Dhabi."](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/96eb249e-cf1a-4c39-9359-f28ed780917b,1760115160002/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C512%2C288%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Aiden-James Einish from the Naskapi Nation of Kawawachikamach in northern Quebec was one of 36 students in Canada selected to attend the Expo-Sciences International science fair in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., Sept. 29 to Oct. 1.
Einish, 16, won the opportunity after receiving a bronze medal at the Canada Wide Science Fair in June. His project looked at how the traditional use of the Labrador Tea plant can reduce inflammation from arthritis.
Einish talked to CBC Indigenous about his experiences in the Middle East and what’s next.

item.title: Gaza: Aid teams repeat calls for unhindered access to stricken enclave
item.description: As displaced Gazans jammed the main route leading north on Friday after the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas reportedly came into effect, UN aid teams repeated their call to open all crossings into the devastated enclave to prevent famine spreading.

item.title: In Africa’s Sahel, conflict and climate change force millions from their homes
item.description: Nearly four million people across Africa’s vast semi-arid Sahel region have been uprooted by a volatile mix of conflict, hunger and climate change, the UN warned on Friday, describing an unfolding protection and survival crisis that is pushing families to flee repeatedly.
item.source:markdown: Nearly four million people across Africa’s vast semi-arid Sahel region have been uprooted by a volatile mix of conflict, hunger and climate change, the UN warned on Friday, describing an unfolding protection and survival crisis that is pushing families to flee repeatedly.

item.title: UN urges restraint as US strikes in southern Caribbean escalate tensions with Venezuela
item.description: The UN on Friday warned of mounting risks to regional peace after a series of US military strikes on boats it accused of drug trafficking left at least 21 dead in the southern Caribbean, prompting Venezuela to declare a state of emergency and denounce the attacks as a breach of international law.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet over US strikes against alleged drug traffickers off Venezuela
item.description: The UN Security Council went into emergency session on Friday, following a request from Venezuela. The United States military has carried out four deadly air strikes in Caribbean waters over the past few weeks against what Washington alleges are Caracas-backed drug traffickers. The Venezuelan Government denies the charge, accusing the administration of being a threat to the peace and security of the whole region. Follow live coverage below and UN News app users can go here.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council went into emergency session on Friday, following a request from Venezuela. item.title: Pope Leo greets Hispanic ministry leaders from the USA
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV met on Tuesday evening in the Vatican with more than a hundred leaders of Hispanic ministry from the United States. He encouraged them to be witnesses of God's love and to accompany especially the poor and migrants. He reminded them that "God never abandons anyone" and thanked them for their pastoral service, calling it a sign of hope and faith in a world wounded by violence and hatred.

Read all

item.title: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act. Here's why it's a controversial move
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump has threatened to invoke the Insurrection Act, which has not been utilized by a U.S. president in more than three decades. Here's a look at why that possibility concerns local officials and some legal analysts.

item.title: Mistissini unveils memorial for residential school survivors and lost children
item.description: Residents of Mistissini took part in a commemorative walk from Voyageur Memorial Elementary School to the shores of Mistissini Lake, where children were once flown out to residential schools, wearing orange in recognition of survivors and those who never came back.
item.source:markdown:

Residents of Mistissini took part in a commemorative walk from Voyageur Memorial Elementary School to the shores of Mistissini Lake, where children were once flown out to residential schools, wearing orange in recognition of survivors and those who never came back.

item.title: Soldier so scared 'knees were trembling' on Bloody Sunday
item.description: One of the soldiers present in Derry on Bloody Sunday said he was so terrified at being "under fire" that his "knees were trembling", the trial of one of his colleagues for two murders has heard.
item.source:markdown: One of the soldiers present in Derry on Bloody Sunday said he was so terrified at being "under fire" that his "knees were trembling", the trial of one of his colleagues for two murders has heard.

item.title: Suspect in deadly wildfire that levelled L.A. neighbourhood fled, then returned to watch fire: prosecutors
item.description: Authorities in California charged a 29-year-old man with starting a fire that days later erupted into the most destructive blaze in Los Angeles history and destroyed much of the Pacific Palisades neighbourhood, U.S. federal law enforcement officials announced Wednesday.
item.source:markdown:
![A neighbourhood by the ocean razed by a fire is seen from above.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/196070f1-5374-43a0-a353-d0a4f4e1f2b1,1759942249564/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C104%2C5280%2C2970%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Authorities in California charged a 29-year-old man with starting a fire that days later erupted into the most destructive blaze in Los Angeles history and destroyed much of the Pacific Palisades neighbourhood, U.S. federal law enforcement officials announced Wednesday.

item.title: U.K. synagogue attacker claimed allegiance to ISIS: police
item.description: The man whose attack on a synagogue in northern England last week resulted in the deaths of two Jewish worshippers phoned police to say he was acting for Islamic State, also known as ISIS, investigators said on Wednesday.

![Police officers stand next to a person in a white hazmat suit.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/ba32e039-8220-47fc-8479-d4358dedebdf,1759941825510/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C285%2C5461%2C3071%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The man whose attack on a synagogue in northern England last week resulted in the deaths of two Jewish worshippers phoned police to say he was acting for Islamic State, also known as ISIS, investigators said on Wednesday.

item.title: Haiti: ‘Unprecedented’ number of children on the run
item.description: The number of children displaced by violence in Haiti has almost doubled in the past year, with 680,000 now uprooted from their homes, a new UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) Child Alert report found.

item.title: DRC Bishops dismayed by death sentence against former President Kabila

item.title: Gold prices hit record high as anxious investors seek safe haven for money
item.description: Gold futures have soared above $4,000 US per troy ounce for the first time, as many investors seek a safe place to park their money as the U.S. government shutdown continues.
item.source:markdown:
![FILE - In this Tuesday, July 22, 2014, file photo, gold bars are stacked in a vault at the United States Mint, in West Point, N.Y. The price of gold has climbed recently as investors scramble for safety amid the widening global trade war. It’s up nearly 5% since May 21, 2019, as stock markets around the world fell, and last week was the best of the year for gold after President Donald Trump surprised markets by threatening to raise tariffs on Mexico. (AP Photo/Mike Groll, File)](https://i.cbc.ca/1.5190145.1742497088!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/off-the-charts-gold.jpg)
Gold futures have soared above $4,000 US per troy ounce for the first time, as many investors seek a safe place to park their money as the U.S. government shutdown continues.

item.title: Pensions, social welfare payments to rise by €10 weekly
item.description: The Government has announced a weekly increase of €10 per person in a range of social protection payments from 2026, including: the State pension, disability allowance, carer's allowance, jobseeker's allowance and one-parent family payment.
item.source:markdown: The Government has announced a weekly increase of €10 per person in a range of social protection payments from 2026, including: the State pension, disability allowance, carer's allowance, jobseeker's allowance and one-parent family payment.

item.description: Minister for Public Expenditure Jack Chambers has announced an increase in the standard capitation rates paid to all schools.
item.source:markdown: Minister for Public Expenditure Jack Chambers has announced an increase in the standard capitation rates paid to all schools.

item.title: 50c on pack of cigarettes, alcohol duty unchanged
item.description: The duty on a pack of 20 cigarettes will be increased by 50c as part of Budget 2026, however excise duty on alcohol is unchanged.
item.source:markdown: The duty on a pack of 20 cigarettes will be increased by 50c as part of Budget 2026, however excise duty on alcohol is unchanged.

item.title: Bob Ross paintings will be auctioned in support of U.S. public TV stations
item.description: Thirty paintings by Ross, whose TV show The Joy of Painting aired on public TV stations in the 1980s and 90s, will be auctioned off with proceeds going to stations that use content from distributor American Public Television. The idea is to help stations in need with licensing fees.

![A photo of a man with a brown afro and a white collared shirt painting a mountain landscape on an easel. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.5660021.1680373189!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/bob-ross.jpeg)
Thirty paintings by Ross, whose TV show The Joy of Painting aired on public TV stations in the 1980s and 90s, will be auctioned off with proceeds going to stations that use content from distributor American Public Television. The idea is to help stations in need with licensing fees.

item.title: Carbon tax to be increased to €71 per tonne of CO2
item.description: Carbon tax is to increase by €7.50 to €71 per tonne of CO2 emitted, which will be applied to auto fuels with effect from tomorrow, and to all other fuels from 1 May 2026.
item.source:markdown: Carbon tax is to increase by €7.50 to €71 per tonne of CO2 emitted, which will be applied to auto fuels with effect from tomorrow, and to all other fuels from 1 May 2026.

item.description: The Government is reducing the VAT rate for food and catering businesses, and for hairdressing services from 13.5% down to 9%.
item.source:markdown: The Government is reducing the VAT rate for food and catering businesses, and for hairdressing services from 13.5% down to 9%.

item.title: Renewables become biggest source of electricity globally for 1st time, beating coal
item.description: Worldwide solar and wind power generation has outpaced electricity demand this year, and for the first time on record, renewable energies combined generated more power than coal, according to a new analysis.
item.source:markdown:
![Workers install solar panels at the under-construction Adani Green Energy Limited's Renewable Energy Park in the salt desert of Karim Shahi village, near Khavda, Bhuj district near the India-Pakistan border in the western state of Gujarat, India, Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. Led by new solar power, the world added renewable energy at breakneck speed in 2023, in an effort to turn away from fossil fuels to stave off severe Earth warming and its effects. (AP Photo/Rafiq Maqbool)](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7653270.1759852762!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/ye-clean-energy.jpg)
Worldwide solar and wind power generation has outpaced electricity demand this year, and for the first time on record, renewable energies combined generated more power than coal, according to a new analysis.

item.title: Man found guilty of stalking Myleene Klass
item.description: A 61-year-old man has been found guilty of stalking TV and radio star Myleene Klass by posting to her an air pistol, handcuffs, a police uniform and "disturbing" unwanted letters.
item.source:markdown: A 61-year-old man has been found guilty of stalking TV and radio star Myleene Klass by posting to her an air pistol, handcuffs, a police uniform and "disturbing" unwanted letters.

item.title: Minimum wage set to increase to €14.15 an hour in 2026
item.description: The Minister for Finance has announced that as of 1 January 2026, the national minimum wage will increase by €0.65 per hour to €14.15 per hour.
item.source:markdown: The Minister for Finance has announced that as of 1 January 2026, the national minimum wage will increase by €0.65 per hour to €14.15 per hour.

item.title: Peter To Rot's witness of martyrdom and morality
item.description:
The story of Blessed Peter To Rot cannot be told apart from the upheavals of World War II. When Japanese forces occupied Papua New Guinea, foreign missionaries were imprisoned, leaving catechists like To Rot to guide local communities in faith. Blessed Peter To Rot’s defiance of polygamy was his ultimate sacrifice. Archbishop Tatamai gives first hand witnesss from stories told.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The story of Blessed Peter To Rot cannot be told apart from the upheavals of World War II. When Japanese forces occupied Papua New Guinea, foreign missionaries were imprisoned, leaving catechists like To Rot to guide local communities in faith. Blessed Peter To Rot’s defiance of polygamy was his ultimate sacrifice. Archbishop Tatamai gives first hand witnesss from stories told.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/martyrdom-and-morality-archbishop-tatamai-reflects-on-his-rela.html)

item.title: Sudan's civil war has faded from headlines, but monitors say it's the largest humanitarian crisis in the world
item.description: The UN says more than 12 million Sudanese have been displaced since its civil war began in spring 2023, making it the largest humanitarian crisis in the world. Aid agencies, including Medecins Sans Frontieres, warn the situation could become even more dire if the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces overruns the besieged city of El Fasher in North Darfur.
item.source:markdown:
![Six people huddle together on a cart piled with their few belongings being pulled by a donkey. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7652882.1759796652!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/sudan-politics-zamzam.JPG)
The UN says more than 12 million Sudanese have been displaced since its civil war began in spring 2023, making it the largest humanitarian crisis in the world. Aid agencies, including Medecins Sans Frontieres, warn the situation could become even more dire if the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces overruns the besieged city of El Fasher in North Darfur.

item.title: Parolin on October 7, Gaza: Human beings are not collateral damage
item.description:
The Holy See Secretary of State speaks to Vatican Media on the second anniversary of Hamas's “inhuman” attack on Israel, which unleashed the destruction of the Gaza Strip. item.title: Darfur: ICC convicts Janjaweed leader of war crimes and crimes against humanity
item.description: Two decades after the scorched-earth campaign that left hundreds of thousands dead in Sudan’s Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has delivered its first conviction linked to the conflict, finding Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman “Ali Kushayb”, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
item.source:markdown: Two decades after the scorched-earth campaign that left hundreds of thousands dead in Sudan’s Darfur, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has delivered its first conviction linked to the conflict, finding Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman “Ali Kushayb”, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

item.title: About 200 hikers await rescue as blizzard hits Mount Everest

item.title: Budget 2026: €10 rise in pension, welfare rates expected
item.description: A €10 increase in the State pension and Social Protection rates is expected in today's Budget. The Budget will also see mortgage interest relief, which has benefitted more than 60,000 householders, extended for another year before being gradually phased out in 2027.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV encourages rekindling awareness of our missionary vocation
item.description:
At the Mass for the Jubilee of the Missions and of Migrants, Pope Leo encourages us to rekindle awareness of our missionary vocation that springs from a desire to “bring the joy and consolation of the Gospel to everyone,” remembering those in difficulty, and in particular “our migrant brothers and sisters” forced to leave their homelands.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: In February 2026 relics of St. Francis of Assisi to be on public display
item.description:
The announcement of the public display for veneration comes from the Sacro Convento in Assisi on the day the Church and the world celebrate the feast of the Saint Francis of Assisi. Thanks to the approval of Pope Leo XIV, the body of the Saint, on the occasion of the 800th anniversary of his death, will be moved from his tomb, located in the crypt of the Franciscan basilica, and placed at the foot of the papal altar in the lower church.

Read all

item.title: Hamas agrees to release remaining hostages as talks set to resume
item.description:
With the Palestinian death toll in Gaza surpassing 67,000, Israel's military says it’s still operating in Gaza City and has warned Palestinians it’s too dangerous to return. Earlier, President Trump told Israel to stop bombing the territory after Hamas said it had accepted part of his peace plan.

item.title: Yukon First Nation uses holograms to preserve the knowledge of elders
item.description: There are fewer than 12 fluent speakers of Northern Tutchone left in the remote community of Mayo, Yukon – and many of them are elderly.  The First Nation of Na-Cho Nyӓk Dun has turned to technology to help preserve the language.
item.source:markdown:
![A child stands with his back to the camera facing a machine about the size of a large vending machine with a glass front and a person (actually a hologram of a person) seated inside. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7650028.1759453598!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/hologram-generator.JPG)
There are fewer than 12 fluent speakers of Northern Tutchone left in the remote community of Mayo, Yukon – and many of them are elderly. The First Nation of Na-Cho Nyӓk Dun has turned to technology to help preserve the language.

item.title: In 4 months, Canadian Jeremy Hansen will blast off to the moon — where he'll also be a human guinea pig
item.description: If all goes to plan, next February could see the return of humans to the moon. Four people — NASA astronauts Victor Glover, Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen — will see it as no one has before. And they will also be collecting valuable health data on themselves.
item.source:markdown:
![A man in a blue astronaut jumpsuit stands with his arms crossed in front of the blue NASA logo.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7649483.1759426815!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/jeremy-hansen-jsc.jpg)
If all goes to plan, next February could see the return of humans to the moon. Four people — NASA astronauts Victor Glover, Reid Wiseman, Christina Koch and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen — will see it as no one has before. And they will also be collecting valuable health data on themselves.

item.title: There could be 'mutual interest' in Canada building its submarines, says German armament secretary
item.description: The notion of Canada becoming a submarine-building nation is not that far-fetched, Germany’s armaments state secretary says. Jens Plötner said ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems — one of two bidders in the submarine program — has done it in other countries and all Canada has to do is ask.
item.source:markdown:
![Four people wear suits and hardhats. One of the holds a model submarine.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7650905.1759520915!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/carney-germany-20250826.jpg)
The notion of Canada becoming a submarine-building nation is not that far-fetched, Germany’s armaments state secretary says. Jens Plötner said ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems — one of two bidders in the submarine program — has done it in other countries and all Canada has to do is ask.

item.title: Guinea-Bissau: Catholics called upon to initiate dialogue and fraternity
item.description:
The Diocese of Bafatá in Guinea-Bissau has celebrated its 25th anniversary with a strong appeal for national fraternity and dialogue. Bishop Victor Luis Quematcha made the call in his Pastoral Letter to the Diocese. Addressed first to Catholics, the Bishop says that the Catholic community should be the first to take steps in dialogue and fraternity, with the view to building a united and inclusive society.

item.title: Wild dogs, disease threaten displaced Gaza families living in landfill
item.description: In Al-Zawaida, in the central Gaza Strip, some families driven out of their homes by the Israel-Hamas war have set up shelter in a landfill. 'I try to protect my kids. I don’t sleep so the dogs don’t come in on us,' Omar Al-Far, 41, says. 'There’s poison and the smell of dead animals.'
item.source:markdown:
![Encampment next to a tall landfill mound](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7a73d8c3-c193-47d9-8223-904d6709348d,1759272712937/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: First Nation calls deteriorating state of Whitehorse dam fish ladder 'extremely concerning'
item.description: According to documents posted on the Yukon Water Board registry, the timbers in a portion of the roughly 366-metre fish ladder are deformed and deteriorating. First identified by staff on Sept. 12, the company has been focused on obtaining an emergency amendment to its new water licence, so it can make needed repairs.
item.source:markdown:
![A very long aparatus, not much wider than an actual ladder, descends a considerable distance above tall shrubs toward the water. It is filled with water and has what appear to be rungs across it. In fact, they are the dividers between tiny pools of slightly different heights that the fish jump through to climb to the top of the dam. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7617541.1759183087!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/fish-ladder.jpg)
According to documents posted on the Yukon Water Board registry, the timbers in a portion of the roughly 366-metre fish ladder are deformed and deteriorating. First identified by staff on Sept. 12, the company has been focused on obtaining an emergency amendment to its new water licence, so it can make needed repairs.

item.title: Hotel costs for gardaí policing match not value - report
item.description: The spending on accommodation for An Garda Síochána members who were policing an UEFA Europa League final in May last year did not represent value for money, according to the Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General's report on the Accounts of the Public Services.
item.source:markdown: The spending on accommodation for An Garda Síochána members who were policing an UEFA Europa League final in May last year did not represent value for money, according to the Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General's report on the Accounts of the Public Services.

item.title: Bovine TB budget exceeded each year since 2020 - C&AG
item.description: Annual expenditure on the State's bovine TB eradication programme has exceeded its budget each year since 2020, according to a report from the State's spending watchdog.
item.source:markdown: Annual expenditure on the State's bovine TB eradication programme has exceeded its budget each year since 2020, according to a report from the State's spending watchdog.

item.title: Pentagon chief tells US military leaders to fix decay
item.description: The US Defense Secretary has said the country's military must fix "decades of decay" as he addressed a rare gathering of hundreds of senior officers summoned from around the world to hear him speak near Washington.
item.source:markdown: The US Defense Secretary has said the country's military must fix "decades of decay" as he addressed a rare gathering of hundreds of senior officers summoned from around the world to hear him speak near Washington.

item.title: Dozens missing, three dead in Indonesia school collapse
item.description: Searchers raced to rescue at least 38 people still believed to be trapped a day after the collapse of an Islamic school building in Indonesia that has already left three dead, authorities said.
item.source:markdown: Searchers raced to rescue at least 38 people still believed to be trapped a day after the collapse of an Islamic school building in Indonesia that has already left three dead, authorities said.

item.title: 'Tried to maintain hope': NHL stars poised for Olympic return in 2026 after long wait
item.description: The NHL's biggest stars are poised to head back under the brightest lights this winter when the league makes its Olympic return at February's 2026 Milan-Cortina showcase in Italy, ending a 12-year absence.
item.source:markdown:
![Male ice hockey players representing Canada wrap their arms around each other in celebration during a game.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7647373.1759252059!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/hko-4-nations-can-swe-05.JPG)
The NHL's biggest stars are poised to head back under the brightest lights this winter when the league makes its Olympic return at February's 2026 Milan-Cortina showcase in Italy, ending a 12-year absence.

item.title: Taliban internet cut sparks Afghanistan telecoms blackout
item.description: The United Nations has called on Afghanistan's Taliban authorities to immediately restore internet and telecommunications in the country, 24 hours after a nationwide blackout was imposed.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations has called on Afghanistan's Taliban authorities to immediately restore internet and telecommunications in the country, 24 hours after a nationwide blackout was imposed.

item.title: Low earners can spend up to 33% of income on healthy food
item.description: Families on low incomes need to spend up to one third (33%) of their weekly income to afford a healthy food basket that meets nutritional needs, according to the latest food basket report from Safefood.
item.source:markdown: Families on low incomes need to spend up to one third (33%) of their weekly income to afford a healthy food basket that meets nutritional needs, according to the latest food basket report from Safefood.

item.title: Ryanair halts winter flights to Tel Aviv on terminal row
item.description: Ryanair said today it will not restart low-fare flights to and from Tel Aviv this winter, as the city's Ben Gurion Airport refused to confirm the airline's summer 2026 slots or guarantee access to its low-cost terminal.
item.source:markdown: Ryanair said today it will not restart low-fare flights to and from Tel Aviv this winter, as the city's Ben Gurion Airport refused to confirm the airline's summer 2026 slots or guarantee access to its low-cost terminal.

item.title: Schwarzenegger: ‘Catholic Church a powerhouse for environmental activism’
item.description:
Ahead of the ‘Raising Hope for Climate Justice’ conference in Castel Gandolfo, Arnold Schwarzenegger speaks to Vatican News about the Church’s vast reach to 1.4 billion Catholics, who have the collective potential to help heal our common home.

Read all

item.title: Iceland's Fly Play to cease all flights, 400 jobs gone
item.description: Fly Play will cease its activities in a move that will hit around 400 employees, the Icelandic airline has said, citing the impact from its weak financial performance and poor ticket sales.

item.title: Gaza: Guterres calls for ‘all parties’ to commit to US peace plan, as UN agencies stress urgent ceasefire need
item.description: The UN Secretary-General António Guterres has welcomed Monday’s Gaza peace deal proposal from US President Donald Trump, urging “all parties” to commit to it.
item.source:markdown: The UN Secretary-General António Guterres has welcomed Monday’s Gaza peace deal proposal from US President Donald Trump, urging “all parties” to commit to it.

item.title: Rohingya plight in Myanmar, a ‘test for humanity’
item.description: “Houses burned. Neighbours killed. Hope vanishing.” With those stark words, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock opened a high-level UN conference on Tuesday, as alarm rises over the impact of Myanmar’s deepening crisis which threatens to destabilise the wider region.
item.source:markdown: “Houses burned. Neighbours killed. Hope vanishing.” With those stark words, General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock opened a high-level UN conference on Tuesday, as alarm rises over the impact of Myanmar’s deepening crisis which threatens to destabilise the wider region.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors authorise new Gang Suppression Force for Haiti
item.description: The UN Security Council has backed a resolution authorising the transition of the Kenyan-led support mission for Haiti into a new Gang Suppression Force, in close cooperation with Haitian authorities. US Ambassador Michael Waltz said it offered new hope for the country's future as “a key first step” to address the humanitarian and security crisis there. Follow the meeting live below; UN News app users need to click here for coverage.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council has backed a resolution authorising the transition of the Kenyan-led support mission for Haiti into a new Gang Suppression Force, in close cooperation with Haitian authorities. US Ambassador Michael Waltz said it offered new hope for the country's future as “a key first step” to address the humanitarian and security crisis there. Follow the meeting live below; UN News app users need to click here for coverage.

item.title: Taliban internet blackout leaves Afghans in limbo while needs surge
item.description: Lifesaving relief efforts to help remote Afghan communities devastated by last month’s deadly earthquake have already been hit by the de facto authorities’ decision to cut internet access nationwide, UN aid agencies said on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Lifesaving relief efforts to help remote Afghan communities devastated by last month’s deadly earthquake have already been hit by the de facto authorities’ decision to cut internet access nationwide, UN aid agencies said on Tuesday.

item.title: DR Congo: Peace still elusive despite ‘progress we see on paper’, UN official says
item.description: Peace in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) “is still mostly a promise”, the head of the UN peacekeeping mission in the country, MONUSCO, told the Security Council on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Peace in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) “is still mostly a promise”, the head of the UN peacekeeping mission in the country, MONUSCO, told the Security Council on Tuesday.

item.title: Breathless in Gaza: Health crisis deepens as families burn plastic for fuel
item.description: Doctors in Gaza are warning of a surge in respiratory illnesses as families – cut off from basic supplies – burn plastic and cardboard to cook and keep warm. They say the outbreak will worsen unless life-saving medicines, fuel and food are allowed into the devastated territory.
item.source:markdown: Doctors in Gaza are warning of a surge in respiratory illnesses as families – cut off from basic supplies – burn plastic and cardboard to cook and keep warm. They say the outbreak will worsen unless life-saving medicines, fuel and food are allowed into the devastated territory.

item.title: From crisis to community cure: A Haitian mother fights back against cholera
item.description: Faced with a deadly outbreak of cholera and a lack of sanitation infrastructure, one Haitian mother sparked a community movement that has transformed her neighbourhood – and saved multiple lives.
item.source:markdown: Faced with a deadly outbreak of cholera and a lack of sanitation infrastructure, one Haitian mother sparked a community movement that has transformed her neighbourhood – and saved multiple lives.

item.title: The UN air service that flies where no one else can
item.description: For George Stroumboulopoulos, WFP Goodwill Ambassador, the only way to get to an inaccessible destination near the border of Chad in 2004 was to fly on an UN Humanitarian Air Service plane: it was the first time he’d ever heard of UNHAS.
item.source:markdown: For George Stroumboulopoulos, WFP Goodwill Ambassador, the only way to get to an inaccessible destination near the border of Chad in 2004 was to fly on an UN Humanitarian Air Service plane: it was the first time he’d ever heard of UNHAS.

item.title: UN Security Council approves new ‘suppression force’ for Haiti amid spiralling gang violence
item.description: The UN Security Council on Tuesday authorized a new multinational Gang Suppression Force (GSF) in Haiti to replace the Kenyan-led security support mission, amid escalating gang violence, widespread rights abuses and a humanitarian emergency affecting all aspects of life in the island nation.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council on Tuesday authorized a new multinational Gang Suppression Force (GSF) in Haiti to replace the Kenyan-led security support mission, amid escalating gang violence, widespread rights abuses and a humanitarian emergency affecting all aspects of life in the island nation.

item.title: New hospital for Mid-West among options given to Govt
item.description: A new hospital in the Mid-West with a second emergency department is one of three options presented to the Government by HIQA, following a review of urgent and emergency healthcare services in the region.
item.source:markdown: A new hospital in the Mid-West with a second emergency department is one of three options presented to the Government by HIQA, following a review of urgent and emergency healthcare services in the region.

item.title: Novo Nordisk planning job cuts at its Irish operation
item.description: Danish pharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk, the maker of blockbuster drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, is planning job cuts at its Irish operation.
item.source:markdown: Danish pharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk, the maker of blockbuster drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, is planning job cuts at its Irish operation.

item.title: Hundreds of Iranians held on U.S. immigration charges to be deported to Iran: Tehran official
item.description: The United States will deport hundreds of Iranians back to Iran in the coming weeks, with the first 120 deportees being prepared for a flight in the next day or two, Iran said Tuesday.
item.source:markdown:
![A fence surrounds the outside the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) building.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7647150.1759239096!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/us-immigration-facilities-security.jpg)

item.title: John Bowman among IMRO Hall of Fame inductees for 2025
item.description: John Bowman, Fr. Brian D'Arcy and Scott Williams have been inducted into the Irish Music Rights Organisation Radio Awards Hall of Fame.
item.source:markdown: John Bowman, Fr. Brian D'Arcy and Scott Williams have been inducted into the Irish Music Rights Organisation Radio Awards Hall of Fame.

item.title: Mother Cabrini Institute Founder: 'We know immigrants and trust them with our lives'
item.description:
In an interview with Vatican News, Michele Pistone, law professor at Villanova University's Charles Widger School of Law, and founding faculty director of Villanova's just-launched Mother Cabrini Institute on Immigration, explains concrete efforts, also to help rediscover the humanity of immigrants whom we so often welcome into the most intimate areas of our lives, like caring for our children and elders.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In an interview with Vatican News, Michele Pistone, law professor at Villanova University's Charles Widger School of Law, and founding faculty director of Villanova's just-launched Mother Cabrini Institute on Immigration, explains concrete efforts, also to help rediscover the humanity of immigrants whom we so often welcome into the most intimate areas of our lives, like caring for our children and elders.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-09/mother-cabrini-institute-immigration-interview-michele-pistone.html)

item.title: 46% of Irish population now have health insurance - HIA
item.description: The number of people with private health insurance rose slightly between April and June, despite a significant spike in the cost of premiums.
item.source:markdown: The number of people with private health insurance rose slightly between April and June, despite a significant spike in the cost of premiums.

item.title: UN appeals to Taliban to restore internet, telecommunications access across Afghanistan
item.description: The United Nations mission in Afghanistan urged the Taliban on Tuesday to restore internet and telecommunications access across the country, saying the blackout imposed by the government in Kabul has left the country almost entirely cut off from the outside world.
item.source:markdown:
![Men try to connect their smart TV to the internet inside their home.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7647138.1759234989!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/afghanistan-internet.JPG)
The United Nations mission in Afghanistan urged the Taliban on Tuesday to restore internet and telecommunications access across the country, saying the blackout imposed by the government in Kabul has left the country almost entirely cut off from the outside world.

item.title: Key points from US peace proposal for Gaza
item.description: The White House has released a 20-point peace proposal that calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, an exchange of hostages held by Hamas for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, a staged Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, and Hamas disarmament.
item.source:markdown: The White House has released a 20-point peace proposal that calls for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, an exchange of hostages held by Hamas for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, a staged Israeli withdrawal from Gaza, and Hamas disarmament.

item.title: Inquiry into CHI care will be 'effective', says Taoiseach
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said the Government will ensure that a promised inquiry into the care of spina bifida and scoliosis patients at Children's Health Ireland (CHI) is "effective" as well as being "transparent and public".
item.source:markdown: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has said the Government will ensure that a promised inquiry into the care of spina bifida and scoliosis patients at Children's Health Ireland (CHI) is "effective" as well as being "transparent and public".

item.description: ɬagət̓ hiyt t̓oxʷʊm Herring to Huckleberries by ošil (Betty Wilson) is written in both English and ʔayʔajuθəm, helping to teach the next generation of Tla'amin their traditional language.

item.title: 'Taking back what was stolen': Lakota teen hoop dancer determined to inspire others
item.description: Traditional teachings were stolen from Davika Ironbow's family. Now the Lakota teen is determined to take them back and share them with other young people.
item.source:markdown:
![A teenage girl stands in a park holding hoops in the shape of the cradle in one hand and then hoops in the shape of the world in the other. ](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7641160.1758650060!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/davika-ironbow-hoop-dancer.JPG)
Traditional teachings were stolen from Davika Ironbow's family. Now the Lakota teen is determined to take them back and share them with other young people.

item.title: Wolf attack in Greece prompts calls for culling rights
item.description: Hunters and farmers in Greece are demanding the right to cull wolves after one attacked a child on a beach this month, warning that the protected species is multiplying in the wild.
item.source:markdown: Hunters and farmers in Greece are demanding the right to cull wolves after one attacked a child on a beach this month, warning that the protected species is multiplying in the wild.

item.title: Kent Monkman's Montreal exhibition challenges colonial gaze with Indigenous narratives
item.description: The exhibit, entitled History is Painted by the Victors, is on display at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts from Sept. 30 until March 8. In his grandiose works, the Cree artist paints colonial scenes that put Indigenous people at the forefront, using a neoclassical style.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman stands in front of large painting by Kent Monkman at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/106cbc95-e759-4879-800d-fdfe6ffc294f,1758734350225/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The exhibit, entitled History is Painted by the Victors, is on display at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts from Sept. 30 until March 8. In his grandiose works, the Cree artist paints colonial scenes that put Indigenous people at the forefront, using a neoclassical style.

item.title: Trump: Hamas has three or four days to respond to deal
item.description: US President Donald Trump has said he is giving Hamas "three or four days" to respond to his Gaza ceasefire plan, under which the group must fully disarm and be excluded from future roles in government.
item.source:markdown: US President Donald Trump has said he is giving Hamas "three or four days" to respond to his Gaza ceasefire plan, under which the group must fully disarm and be excluded from future roles in government.

item.title: Iranian director Jafar Panahi defies censors again
item.description: The Iranian director Jafar Panahi, whose latest film won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May, has told AFP he will continue to defy his country's censors and ignore the risk of returning to prison.

item.title: 'We haven't lost our language': How Opaskwayak Cree Nation's immersive program shapes new speakers
item.description: The melody of kids singing O Canada in Cree rings through Joe A. Ross School’s intercom speakers and echoes through the building. It’s how classes at the Opaskwayak Cree Nation school start each morning, but their use of Cree doesn’t end there.
item.source:markdown:
![A man and a young boy sit at a desk.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7647028.1759242138!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/ronin-hall-teacher.JPG)
The melody of kids singing O Canada in Cree rings through Joe A. Ross School’s intercom speakers and echoes through the building. It’s how classes at the Opaskwayak Cree Nation school start each morning, but their use of Cree doesn’t end there.

item.title: Tanning elk hide is a step toward truth and reconciliation for these Indigenous educators
item.description: Kelly Gordon and Elder Larry Mistaken Chief have been leading hide tanning workshops together for the last five years, with the goal of creating opportunities for unity and healing, while promoting truth and reconciliation.
item.source:markdown:
![Two people with an elk hide.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7646059.1759108059!/fileImage/httpImage/image.JPG_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/hide-tanning.JPG)
Kelly Gordon and Elder Larry Mistaken Chief have been leading hide tanning workshops together for the last five years, with the goal of creating opportunities for unity and healing, while promoting truth and reconciliation.

item.title: Starmer says UK at fork between decency and division
item.description: The British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has warned his party that the UK stands at a fork in the road between decency and division.

item.title: Nicole Kidman and Keith Urban have reportedly separated
item.description: The Oscar-winning actress Nicole Kidman and country music star Keith Urban have separated after 19 years of marriage, various news outlets have reported, citing unidentified sources.
item.source:markdown: The Oscar-winning actress Nicole Kidman and country music star Keith Urban have separated after 19 years of marriage, various news outlets have reported, citing unidentified sources.

item.title: Parent of neurodivergent children speaks of difficulties
item.description: The Ombudsman for Children has called for maternity hospitals to record the number of disabled children born annually. As part of a series examining disability services in Ireland, our Social Affairs Correspondent Ailbhe Conneely reports on the difficulties for parents of disabled children.
item.source:markdown: The Ombudsman for Children has called for maternity hospitals to record the number of disabled children born annually. As part of a series examining disability services in Ireland, our Social Affairs Correspondent Ailbhe Conneely reports on the difficulties for parents of disabled children.

item.title: Gardaí make fresh appeal to find killers of Dessie Fox
item.description: Gardaí have made a fresh appeal for information to find the killers of Co Tyrone bookmaker Dessie Fox, 35 years on.
item.source:markdown: Gardaí have made a fresh appeal for information to find the killers of Co Tyrone bookmaker Dessie Fox, 35 years on.

item.title: Comedians performing at Saudi Arabia comedy festival called out for 'whitewashing' country's regime
item.description: Some of the world's biggest comedians, including Dave Chappelle, Louis C.K., Pete Davidson and Kevin Hart, are performing at the Riyadh Comedy Festival — but not everyone is laughing. Some other comics and the non-profit group Human Rights Watch, have criticized those performing, noting the country's record of human rights abuses.
item.source:markdown:
![three men in suits pictured on red carpets in this composite image](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7646993.1759190923!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/chapelle-davidson-ck-composite.jpg)
Some of the world's biggest comedians, including Dave Chappelle, Louis C.K., Pete Davidson and Kevin Hart, are performing at the Riyadh Comedy Festival — but not everyone is laughing. Some other comics and the non-profit group Human Rights Watch, have criticized those performing, noting the country's record of human rights abuses.

item.title: How a landmark 1983 adoption case left a First Nations girl trying to 'not be brown anymore'
item.description: Leticia Racine was just seven when the Supreme Court ruled that her foster parents should be allowed to adopt her. She has spent over 40 years untangling that decision and understanding its impact on other Indigenous kids in Canada.
item.source:markdown:
![Leticia stands next to Linda and leans her head against Linda who's smiling.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645291.1759430959!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpeg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/leticia-racine-and-linda-daniels.jpeg)
Leticia Racine was just seven when the Supreme Court ruled that her foster parents should be allowed to adopt her. She has spent over 40 years untangling that decision and understanding its impact on other Indigenous kids in Canada.

item.title: 'Never give up hope': Percy Onabigon is home after First Nation family spent decades repatriating his remains
item.description: With the repatriation of his remains, Percy Onabigon has finally returned to Long Lake #58 First Nation, 79 years after he was taken from the northern community and put into a residential school in southwestern Ontario. Here's what his reburial means to his family and community leaders, and why they're calling for more support to help others repatriate lost loved ones.
item.source:markdown:
![A person wearing a black and orange ribbon skirt is seen placing her hand on a casket,](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7645736.1759010228!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/claire-onabigon.jpg)
With the repatriation of his remains, Percy Onabigon has finally returned to Long Lake #58 First Nation, 79 years after he was taken from the northern community and put into a residential school in southwestern Ontario. Here's what his reburial means to his family and community leaders, and why they're calling for more support to help others repatriate lost loved ones.

item.title: YouTube to pay $22m in settlement with Trump
item.description: YouTube has agreed to pay $22m (€18.7m) to settle a lawsuit filed by US President Donald Trump after the company suspended his account over the 6 January 2021 attack on the Capitol, according to a court filing.
item.source:markdown: YouTube has agreed to pay $22m (€18.7m) to settle a lawsuit filed by US President Donald Trump after the company suspended his account over the 6 January 2021 attack on the Capitol, according to a court filing.

item.title: Tánaiste to update Cabinet on Troubles legacy agreement
item.description: Tánaiste Simon Harris will update Cabinet on the recent agreement with the UK on dealing with the legacy of Northern Ireland's Troubles, including a Government commitment to provide €25 million to support victims and families over the next three years
item.source:markdown: Tánaiste Simon Harris will update Cabinet on the recent agreement with the UK on dealing with the legacy of Northern Ireland's Troubles, including a Government commitment to provide €25 million to support victims and families over the next three years

item.title: Increase in number of workers changing jobs - survey
item.description: Job turnover at Irish workplaces has surged to a record high, according to a new survey from Microsoft Ireland.

item.title: Social housing vacancy rate decreased in 2024
item.description: The average social housing vacancy rate decreased last year from 2.81% in 2023 to 2.75%, with 4,251 units vacant at the end of 2024.
item.source:markdown: The average social housing vacancy rate decreased last year from 2.81% in 2023 to 2.75%, with 4,251 units vacant at the end of 2024.

item.title: Nearly 100 children hurt, several feared dead and dozens trapped after Indonesian school collapses
item.description: At least three students were killed, with many others injured and dozens were presumed buried in the unstable concrete rubble of a collapsed school building in Indonesia early Tuesday.
item.source:markdown:
![A man and woman, both crying, with rescue workers behind them](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7647072.1759200712!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/indonesia-school-collapsed.jpg)
At least three students were killed, with many others injured and dozens were presumed buried in the unstable concrete rubble of a collapsed school building in Indonesia early Tuesday.

item.title: Man charged with murder of three members of his family
item.description: A man has appeared in court charged with the murder of three of his family members in Co Louth.
item.source:markdown: A man has appeared in court charged with the murder of three of his family members in Co Louth.

item.title: These American cities are bracing for a federal troop surge
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump has called the expansion of federal immigration agents and National Guard troops into Chicago, Memphis, Tenn., and Portland, Ore., necessary, blasting Democrats for crime and lax immigration policies. Here's the latest from on the ground in the three cities expecting to see more federal law enforcement in the coming days.
item.source:markdown:
![A federal agent wears sunglasses and a helmet as he stares into the distance.](https://i.cbc.ca/1.7647086.1759205510!/cpImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/immigration-chicago.jpg)
U.S. President Donald Trump has called the expansion of federal immigration agents and National Guard troops into Chicago, Memphis, Tenn., and Portland, Ore., necessary, blasting Democrats for crime and lax immigration policies. Here's the latest from on the ground in the three cities expecting to see more federal law enforcement in the coming days.
